awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Structure and Interpolation in Number Theory and Beyond
awd_abstract_narration:
The principal investigator (PI) will investigate connections between seemingly disparate data arising in number theory, a field of mathematics with deep ties to many areas in sciences and engineering. In particular, the PI will study structures associated to the whole numbers, fractions, and related sets called "number fields." The PI aims to elucidate how these structures vary across certain infinite collections of number fields, and furthermore, how their behavior explains currently mysterious phenomena in number theory, geometry, and beyond. In the course of the project the PI will organize workshops to educate graduate students about recent research developments and to promote diverse collaborations.  To engage undergraduate students in topics motivating her research, the PI will develop an innovative, interactive course integrating approaches from the arts. Partly through a collaboration with museum curators, the PI will also organize public exhibits for the broader community.

The research in this project focuses on L-functions, automorphic forms, and p-adic methods as tools to understand particular structures and how they vary in families. Anticipated consequences include progress toward instances of the Greenberg-Iwasawa main conjectures (connecting the structures of Galois groups with p-adic L-functions) and the Bloch-Kato conjectures (equating ranks of certain groups with the order of vanishing of associated L-functions at the central point, in analogy with the Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer conjecture). Key components, which are interconnected so that progress on one advances the others, include investigating the interplay between p-adic and archimedean properties of L-functions and automorphic forms, studying p-adic aspects of unitary Shimura varieties, and bridging different approaches to p-adic automorphic forms to gain insight into the behavior of associated data whose significance extends into number theory, homotopy theory, and arithmetic geometry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant funded research, education, and outreach in number theory, a central area of mathematics.  

The research developed tools and methods for tackling key problems in number theory.  It focused on developing new insights and connections between algebraic, geometric, and analytic objects.  The research particularly focused on L-functions and automorphic forms, two objects that play a powerful role in modern number theory.  The PI's research produced new results about L-functions, especially about their p-adic and archimedean behavior and the interplay between these.  Along the way, the PI also developed new results for automorphic forms and related geometric spaces, especially in the setting of unitary groups.  The PI disseminated her results in peer-reviewed journals and in 50 invited lectures to a variety of audiences.


The project resulted in substantial broader impacts, including:
1. Organization of a museum exhibit to share a creative side of math with the broader public.  The in-person Creativity Counts exhibit took place at the Jordan Schnitzer Museum of Art for 3 months in 2021.  In addition, there is a virtual version of the exhibit that became the museum's most-visited virtual exhibit and has been available now for over 3 years.  An associated website has been visited by people from over 56 countries and 340 cities. https://jsma.uoregon.edu/CreativityCounts


2. Creation of a new course.  The PI created a new course, "Math and the Creative Process: A Participatory Exploration of Number Theory," to introduce undergraduates to aspects of creative problem solving early in their education.  The course integrated approaches from the arts, and students contributed pieces to the aforementioned museum exhibit. https://pages.uoregon.edu/eeischen/CreativityCounts/course/


3. Improv.  The PI led a project to integrate principles of improv(isational theater) into the classroom.  She initially developed these exercises as tools to help her students develop certain skills in the aforementioned Math and the Creative Process course.  With a consultant hired on the grant, she also developed workshops that introduce these exercises to other instructors.  This has led to further, ongoing projects. 


4. Facilitating new research.  The PI created the APAW workshops in 2022, which facilitated new research directions.  Several research papers have already resulted from new collaborations that began at APAW.


5. Mentoring students.  The PI supervised students at both the graduate and undergraduate levels.


6. Talking with a variety of audiences.  The PI gave talks to audiences ranging from experts in her research to high school students to the broader public.  Some of the broader impact activities from this grant are discussed in an interview with her here: https://www.numberphile.com/podcast/ellen-eischen
